title: LOCKED ROOM PUZZLE
name: locked
blurb: The CFAR Alumni Reunion is usually run as an "unconference," in which participants create their own lectures and activities.  Rather than giving my take on some facet of rationality, I decided to create an applied challenge, giving my fellow alums the chance to test their thinking and planning skills against a locked room full of clues.

title: TURTLES
name: turtles
blurb: "Turtles" is the name I gave to a set of small, portable stepping stones I built for parkour practice, useful for precision landings, strides, and boosted takeoffs.  I left the original set of four at the gym in Seattle, and built a second, more refined pair to take with me for my own training.

title: FRANKENTWIX
name: frankentwix
blurb: Ankle-height railings, artificial stepping stones, and low curb-height wooden blocks are all common pieces of equipment in parkour gyms around the world. In this project, I combined all three into a single, versatile, portable training tool. Excellent for balance, precision, strides, broad jumps, and all kinds of physical conditioning.

title: UNKNOWN UNKNOWNS
name: arch
blurb: Originally designed as a part of my sixth grade curriculum, I rebuilt this eight-foot high problem for the Inflection Point kids' rationality camp.  Typically, it is presented to students disassembled and jumbled together, with no hints as to what it should be or what is expected of them.  Solving the problem requires teamwork, persistence, and most of all a set of clear heads.

title: OBSTACLE COURSE DESIGN
name: gym
blurb: During my two years at the parkour gym in Seattle, my equipment and equipment designed and built by the other employees were arranged into a fantastic range of courses and challenges.  These are some of the more interesting setups that were either built by me, inspired by the curriculum I wrote, or constructed using obstacles I created.

title: SCHOOL FLYER
name: flyer
blurb: One of my most useful qualifications for working with the Seattle parkour gym was my experience with running an afterschool parkour club as a middle school teacher.  During my time there, I helped develop several programs and standards for working with elementary, middle, and high schools.

title: MAGIC DECK BOX
name: deckbox
blurb: In the trading card game Magic: The Gathering, you assemble various decks of cards to play with.  I wanted to create a set of five decks (one for each color in the game) and keep them together in a small, classy case that I could take with me when I wanted to teach beginners.  None of the cases for sale met my requirements, so I made my own.

title: STRUCTURES
name: structures
blurb: In the trading card game Magic: The Gathering, there are many play variants requiring special cards. Structures are a variant I designed, complete with their own rules, introducing conquerable territory into the game.  The final versions were printed on label paper and applied to Magic cards to create an authentic look.

title: THE TRACEUR'S METHOD
name: method
blurb: This is one of several infographics I created for the walls of the Seattle parkour gym.  The goal was to have a poster that would be interesting at a glance, for ten seconds, or for five minutes, depending on who was reading and how long they were standing there.  It was ultimately printed as a five-foot-high vinyl banner and mounted by the door.

title: PORTO-WALL, MARK II
name: mark2
blurb: When I arrived in Seattle, one of the biggest gaps in the equipment set of the local parkour gym was any kind of wall that could be climbed or vaulted OVER (rather than simply onto). This was my second attempt at building a sturdy, portable wall that could be used for training a variety of movements.

title: JUCANTE
name: jucante
blurb: Together with my friends in Seattle, I designed, developed, printed, and playtested a complete Magic: The Gathering expansion of 249 cards, centered around a world loosely inspired by Robert Jordan's Blight in the Wheel of Time series.  A "spoiler" article for the set can be found on this site, under Writing.

title: FATHER'S DAY
name: whist
blurb: When I stumbled across a two-page excerpt in Edgar Allan Poe's "The Murders in the Rue Morgue" extolling the virtues of whist and whist players, I knew that I had found the seed of the perfect Father's Day present.  Completed using Inkscape and photos from the Pershing Room at West Point Military Academy, where my father spent years playing.

title: TIKI TOPPERS
name: tiki
blurb: The Seattle parkour gym had an excellent set of 3'x3' square-based boxes called "Tikis" that could stack and nest like LEGOs.  However, I felt that the boring flat tops were a waste of potential, and began designing a set of "Tiki tops" that would present a wider range of opportunities and challenges at various heights.

title: BOXES, BLOCKS, BARS, & MORE
name: equip
blurb: In addition to the specific equipment detailed above, I also designed and built many vault boxes, launching and landing platforms, and portable/modular rails and bars.  By the time I left the gym in Seattle to head for the Bay, roughly half of the objects inside were the result of my work.

title: WEB DESIGN
name: sites
blurb: While considering whether to start a parkour gym or join an existing one in Seattle, Washington, I created the following two website concepts using the vector graphics program Inkscape.  Although neither site was ever implemented, I retained elements of each for use in other projects.

title: CHESSCRAFT
name: chesscraft
blurb: One of my "someday" projects is to create a game that falls somewhere in the middle of the spectrum defined by chess on one end and Starcraft on the other - a turn-based strategy game with deterministic, predictable combat that nevertheless resembles the chaos of real conflict.  This is the digital board that "Chesscraft" will be played on.

title: ENDER AWARD
name: award
blurb: There's that truism where everyone says amazing things about you at your funeral, but no one says them while you're still around.  To correct this, I often created plaques and awards for students and colleagues, to acknowledge achievements not given official recognition.  This award was presented to a few of my students at the end of each year.

title: BRIDGE
name: bridge
blurb: As a part of my sixth grade Core Connections curriculum, my students built and stress tested/smashed popsicle stick bridges, many of which held up well over 100 pounds distributed across their decks. In my second year, I built the following bridge as an example.

title: TRAPPED IN THE PAST
name: past
blurb: I've always been a fan of trivia, especially the kind that was arguably actually worth knowing.  In 2010, Ryan North (of "Dinosaur Comics" fame) released a fact-packed shirt that was, in essence, a time-traveler's cheat sheet.  Inspired, I copied the basic idea, expanded the text eightfold, and printed it up as a vinyl banner to nerd-snipe sixth graders in my classroom.

title: THE NOVAN ALPHABET
name: novan
blurb: During my freshman year of high school, while taking the mandatory "freshman seminar" class on balancing checkbooks and using condoms, I allowed my attention to wander sufficiently far enough that I ended up inventing my own phonetic alphabet.  For two years, I used it to write secret journal entries.  Later on, I would receive extra credit in a college linguistics class for digging it out of my archives.
